ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Heritrix sends email?
ygData.msgSnippet: In this case, it s not the crawler that s sending any email, but the server-side script it s hitting, which is specified in the FORM ACTION attribute. For

In this case, it's not the crawler that's sending any email, but the
server-side script it's hitting, which is specified in the FORM
ACTION attribute.

For example, from the form page:

   http://www2.siba.fi/tapahtuu/lomake.htm

I was able to send myself email by sending my browser to:

   http://www2.siba.fi/cgi-bin/tilauskonsertit?[MY-ADDRESS]

Heritrix is visiting (with a GET) this target URI, even though
it is specified on the form as a POST action. That's somewhat
aggressive, but usually harmless. In this case, it's triggering
the server's form-accept script to send mail to the given
address, and in the absence of form-values supplied it seems to
be using the request-headers.

- Gordon @ Bitzi


Kaisa Kaunonen wrote:
> Hi,
> does Heritrix send web forms forward to email addresses?
> 
> Namely, a local Sibelius-Academy keeps a web form where you can order
> their students to perform at various happenings for a fee. You fill in
> your info, press a submit-button and send the info to an email address
> associated with the form.
> 
> The web form, although an empty one, was sent to their press manager.
> She got the impression that we might be interested to have one of
> their student bands here at our library.
> 
> She received the the form and got this information about sender
> from = hyk-webcrawler@...  		
>    [this is our contact address in order.xml]
> sender's machine or proxy = nwa6a.lib.helsinki.fi        
>    [machine where heritrix runs]
> browser = mozilla/5.0 (compatible; heritrix/1.0.4
> +http://www.lib.helsinki.fi/)
> web form = 
> 
> This is actually not a problem since I haven't heard of anything
> similar before. Just curious how it happened. If anybody is
> interested, the form is at (3rd link on the left side)
> http://www2.siba.fi/tapahtuu/tilauskonsertit.html
> 
>
